title: Targeting Meritocracy
summary:
Key ideas
- Many publications have been criticizing meritocracy, claiming that elites send their children to private schools, then to Harvard, where they get all A+s and end up in high-paying management positions.
- Freddie de Boer is against meritocracy because he rejects the idea of human deserts.
- Being a meritocrat means choosing the best decision-maker possible, not necessarily the smartest person.
- Success in college only weakly correlates with success in the real world.
- There should be a distinction between education and merit.
- Reworking every field on the model of programming can potentially create a real meritocracy.

Key learnings
- Many publications and individuals have different views on meritocracy.
- The word meritocracy should mean decision by merit, rather than by wealth, class, race, or education.
- Success in college only weakly correlates with success in the real world.

Key questions
- What is the distinction between education and merit?
- How can every field be reworked on the model of programming?
- Can a true meritocracy ever exist?
